docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Secretary of State DeForest B. Soaries Jr. dipped his toe into the murky pool of gubernatorial politics last month -- suggesting that the next governor of the state should be a member of a minority group, or maybe even himself -- he unleashed a riptide. Although Mr. Soaries, or Buster, as he is invariably known around the State House, quickly and inexplicably withdrew his name from consideration, the issues he raised remain on the table.

headline.main: Ready for a Black Governor? If Not Now, When?

docs.abstract: Article on storm of controversy that arose when New Jersey Secretary of State DeForest B Soaries Jr suggested that next governor be member of minority group, possibly himself; Soaries has since withdrawn his name from consideration but there is growing sentiment among many blacks that state should have black governor; brief profiles of some potential candidates; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: While on vacation, I witnessed two cousins (not my relatives) at a slot machine. The first had been at the machine for hours. No sooner had she walked away than her cousin took over and, on her first try, scored big time. There's a rule of thumb in one-armed-bandit gambling -- never look back at a machine you've left. The first woman didn't follow this rule, and with lights flashing and horns blaring, saw and heard her cousin's victory. She was distraught, however, when the winning cousin refused to split her profits 50-50. Which cousin was right? -- Joseph Perpich, Maryland My understanding of slot-machine ethics conforms to that rule of thumb you cite: when someone sits down at a machine, it is as if the world were created anew. Nothing that happened earlier has any relevance; each pull of the handle means a fresh start, which is both the thrill and the terror of gambling. Thus a player owes nothing to whoever sat at the machine before, and family ties don't change that.

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 01-28-01: The Ethicist; Odds and Ends

docs.abstract: Randy Cohen The Ethicist column on ethics that do not require cousin to share winnings with cousin who had just left that very same slot machine; on 'fudging' date-of-onset of speech problems so that elderly patients are covered by Medicare (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: An entry-level health insurance plan said to cost 35 percent less than the least expensive H.M.O. is being offered to Long Island employers who offer no health insurance to their employees. Developed by Vytra Health Plans in Melville, the coverage, called SmartStart, is designed to cover the estimated 300,000 workers who have no health insurance, said Tom McAteer, president of Vytra.

docs.lead_paragraph: SAYING that the county has an interest in ''supporting all caring, committed and responsible family units,'' the Westchester County Executive, Andrew J. Spano, has proposed a bill to create a Domestic Partner Registry for adult couples involved in long-term relationships. Mr. Spano has sent the measure to the Board of Legislators, which adopted a resolution in September supporting such a registry. The 17-member board must hold a public hearing on the bill before it can vote on it.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Justice Dept. Finds Success Chasing Health Care Fraud'' (front page, Jan. 23): Medicare's ever-changing rules swallow up resources that should be devoted to patients, not paperwork.
docs.abstract: Letter from Dr D Ted Lewers says American Medical Assn, of which he is chairman, will support Bush administration's efforts to identify health care fraud, but these efforts must not criminalize honest mistakes; claims Medicare's ever-changing rules swallow up resources that should be devoted to patients, not paperwork
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Justice Dept. Finds Success Chasing Health Care Fraud'' (front page, Jan. 23):    Medicare's ever-changing rules swallow up resources that should be devoted to patients, not paperwork.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten floors above the bail bondsmen, the sunburned homeless and the wedding ministers-for-hire that dominate downtown, Mayor Oscar B. Goodman of Las Vegas looks out at the gleaming carpet of urban expansion covering the Mojave Desert as far as the eye can see and utters a civic blasphemy. ''Look at all those gated communities, those big beautiful houses where people don't know their neighbors and never talk to anyone,'' Mr. Goodman says. ''It's nothing but -- I'm not supposed to say this -- sprawl!''

headline.main: Las Vegas Bet on Growth But Doesn't Love Payoff

docs.abstract: Las Vegas, Nev, metropolitan area is fastest-growing region in country, with 2000 census showing it adding it about 70,000 people a year; now has population of 1.4 million; troubles abound for city because of such rapid growth, from bad air to choked traffic to diminishing water supply to squalid downtown ignored by big-money casinos that are just beyond city limits on Las Vegas Strip; Mayor Oscar B Goodman says he is concerned about such urban sprawl, and wants core of his city to have 'some culture'--shops, grocery stores, bookstores, apartments, museums and all the other ingredients of a healthy downtown; Goodman photo; US Geological Survey photos show growth of Las Vegas (L)
docs.snippet: Ten floors above the bail bondsmen, the sunburned homeless and the wedding ministers-for-hire that dominate downtown, Mayor Oscar B. Goodman of Las Vegas looks out at the gleaming carpet of urban expansion covering the Mojave Desert as far as the eye...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE City Council has been busy caring for everyone else's children this week. It voted unanimously to make them wear helmets when riding scooters, and the Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, defended his proposed new smoking restrictions in restaurants by saying, ''My concern here is basically for children and the health effects of smoking.'' Devotion to children is a wonderful thing, but it can seem a little too wonderful when proclaimed by politicians. Children, after all, are not eligible to vote. When politicians start talking about laws to protect kids, the first question to ask is: which adults are going to benefit?

headline.main: The Big City; Legislating A Childhood Without Risk

docs.abstract: John Tierney The Big City column deplores overprotectiveness of baby boomers toward their children, and cites two New York City Council regulations passed this week; one prohibits smoking in all areas of restaurants and another forces children to wear helmets while riding scooters; contends that these laws make parents feel safer and politicians look virtuous (M)
docs.snippet: THE City Council has been busy caring for everyone else's children this week. It voted unanimously to make them wear helmets when riding scooters, and the Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, defended his proposed new smoking restrictions in...

docs.lead_paragraph: To address a crisis in Medicare, Congress recently provided more money to health maintenance organizations in the hope that they would return to the federal program, increase benefits and reduce premiums for Medicare beneficiaries. But that has not happened. H.M.O. executives said today that they had decided to use most of the money to increase payments to doctors and hospitals, not to expand benefits for elderly and disabled people who depend on Medicare, as many in Congress had intended.

headline.main: New Money for H.M.O.'s Isn't Going as Congress Intended

docs.abstract: Congress's move to provide more money to health maintenance orgns in hope that they will return to federal program, increase benefits and reduce premiums for Medicare beneficiaries has not worked out; HMO execs say that they have decided to use most of money to increase payments to doctors and hospitals, not to expand benefits for elderly and disabled people who depend on Medicare, as many in Congress had intended (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The wages and benefits of United States workers rose solidly in the fourth quarter, wrapping up a year that posted the biggest annual gain in compensation costs since 1991, government figures showed today. The Labor Department reported that its employment cost index, a closely watched gauge of inflation, rose a seasonally adjusted 0.8 percent in the last three months of 2000, down from a 0.9 percent rise in the third quarter. That reflected a job market that cooled late in the year from a red-hot pace.

headline.main: Wages Showed Strong Gain In 4th Quarter

docs.abstract: Labor Department reports its employment cost index rose seasonally adjusted 0.8 percent in last quarter of 2000, down from 0.9 percent rise in third quarter; sales of existing homes slipped 7.4 percent in December, to annual rate of 4.87 million units (S)
